clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of the Sustained Viral Response of Chronic Hepatitis c After Treatment With Direct Action Antivirals
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of the Sustained Viral Response on the Natural History Chronic Hepatitis c After Treatment With Direct Action Antivirals

lead_sponsor.agency: Fundación Pública Andaluza para la gestión de la Investigación en Sevilla

clinical_study.source: Fundación Pública Andaluza para la gestión de la Investigación en Sevilla

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the evolution of liver injury with fibrosis data obtained using non-invasive serological markers in patients who achieved SVR after treatment with direct-acting antivirals.

detailed_description.textblock: This open study includes patients with chronic hepatitis C who received treatment with the new direct-acting antivirals between November 1, 2014 and December 31, 2017, who achieved a sustained viral response at week 12.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients with a progression of liver injury.
primary_outcome.description: To assess the evolution of liver injury with fibrosis data in patients who achieved SVR after treatment with direct-acting antivirals.

secondary_outcome.measure: Identify patients who develop liver-related events (liver decompensation, hepatocellular carcinoma, and death) after achieving sustained viral response.
secondary_outcome.description: Development of hepatic decompensation, defined as a patient with ascites, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (PBR), digestive bleeding of varicose origin, or hepatic encephalopathy at some point in the evolution from SVR until the end of study follow-up.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rate of risk factors presented by patients.
secondary_outcome.description: Identify risk factors in patients who develop liver complications after achieving sustained viral response.

secondary_outcome.measure: Absence of improvement in non-invasive fibrosis parameters vs the development of liver complications.
secondary_outcome.description: To determine if there is a relationship between the absence of improvement in non-invasive fibrosis parameters and the development of liver complications.
To compare the clinical and fibrosis data between patients who develop liver complications and those who do not.

study_pop.textblock: The study population are patients with chronic hepatitis C who have been treated with direct-acting antivirals between 2014 and 2017. Also patients with fibrosis and liver cirrhosis.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with chronic liver disease caused by virus C.
- Have received treatment with the new DAAs between November 1, 2014 and December 1, 2017.
- Patients diagnosed with advanced fibrosis and liver cirrhosis. Advanced fibrosis was defined as a Fibroscan> 10 kPa, an APRI index> 1.5 and / or a FIB-4 index> 3.25. For its part, cirrhosis was defined such as a Fibroscan> 12.5 kPa and / or presence of esophagogastric varices in the endoscopic study and / or data portal hypertension ultrasound.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Coinfection by virus B or HIV.
- Development of HCC before or during treatment.
- Abuse of alcohol intake or addiction to parenteral drugs.
- Liver disease of non-viral etiology (autoimmune, toxic, metabolic).
